mainmatter.p: Given a sheaf \mathscr { O } of rings, we can define a subsheaf \mathscr { O } ^ \times consisting of the invertible elements, i.e. \Gamma (U, \mathscr { O } ^ \times ) = \Gamma (U, \mathscr { O } )^ \times. This is the subsheaf of units.
This can be equivalently expressed as a pullback of \mathscr { O } \times \mathscr { O } \xrightarrow {(f,g) \mapsto f g} \mathscr { O } and 1 \xrightarrow {1} \mathscr { O }.

Given two locally ringed spaces, a morphism of ringed spaces \varphi between them is local when sections of \varphi ^{-1} \mathscr { O } _Y are invertible iff their images in \mathscr { O } _X are invertible, i.e. the following diagram is a pullback:

mainmatter.p: Note that the subsheaf of units is given by a finite limit, hence \varphi ^{-1} preserves it. Since the lower map map \varphi ^{-1} \mathscr { O } _Y \to \mathscr { O } _X is a ring homomorphism on the sections, it maps units to units. Hence restriction to the upper map makes sense.
